text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

Our generation will
be defined by how

we manage today's digital
tools, and how we cultivate

the next generation
of technologies
that will shape our tomorrow.

Technology has enabled
so much, but it's also

raised important questions about
things like privacy, fairness,
and impact.

New tech can be the foundation
of a more prosperous society,

but only if we build it
responsibly and with purpose.

I come from a family
of public servants.

My parents were US
Foreign Service officers

and raised my sisters
and I while serving
in missions around the world.

Their example
inspired me and still

inspires me to strive
to make a contribution.

I went to college
in Silicon Valley,

and I became excited
by how technology
was transforming society.

That led me to
Google, where I was

able to see that impact more
directly, and now to Harvard,

where I'm a joint-degree student
between HBS and the Harvard
Kennedy School.

My mission is to
ensure that technology

serves the public interest,
that it helps people.

I believe that innovation can
help solve the world's most

pressing problems,
and that everyone
should benefit from it equally.

Over the long term,
I intend to work

across business and government
to make that happen.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
